name: Taseko Mines Limited
description: Taseko Mines Limited is a mining company focused on the production and exploration of copper and other minerals. Founded in 1966 and headquartered in Vancouver, British Columbia, Canada, Taseko operates the Gibraltar Mine, one of the largest copper-molybdenum mines in Canada. The company is committed to developing sustainable mining practices and has implemented various initiatives to minimize its environmental impact while maximizing community benefits. Taseko also has several other projects in various stages of development, including the Florence Copper project in Arizona, which utilizes an innovative in-situ copper recovery method that is environmentally friendly and efficient. With a strong emphasis on operational excellence, Taseko strives to enhance shareholder value through disciplined capital allocation and resource development. The company is dedicated to maintaining a safe workplace for its employees and fostering positive relationships with local communities. As the global demand for copper continues to rise due to its essential role in renewable energy technologies and electric vehicles, Taseko is well positioned to capitalize on this trend.

seo.meta_title: Taseko Mines Limited | Sustainable Copper Mining
seo.meta_description: Taseko Mines Limited is a mining company focused on copper production and exploration. Learn about Taseko's operations, sustainability efforts, and growth projects.

faq.question: What does Taseko Mines primarily produce?
faq.answer: Taseko Mines primarily produces copper and molybdenum.

faq.question: Where is Taseko Mines headquartered?
faq.answer: Taseko Mines is headquartered in Vancouver, British Columbia, Canada.

faq.question: What is the Gibraltar Mine?
faq.answer: The Gibraltar Mine is one of the largest copper-molybdenum mines in Canada, operated by Taseko Mines.

faq.question: What is the Florence Copper project?
faq.answer: The Florence Copper project is an in-situ copper recovery project located in Arizona, utilizing environmentally friendly methods.
